brief_summary.textblock:
To conduct a pooled analysis of NHANES I/II data on race, gender, and coronary heart
      disease.

clinical_study.brief_title: Pooled Analysis of NHANES I/II--Race, Gender, and CHD

detailed_description.textblock:
BACKGROUND:

      Over the last 25 years, a sustained and marked decline in death rates from coronary heart
      disease (CHD) has occurred for all major segments of the U.S. population. Recently, however,
      the decline has proceeded less rapidly in blacks than in whites, and in women than men.
      These trends have focused further attention on possible heterogeneity in the risk factor
      patterns among the demographic sub-groups. Previous studies of CHD risk factors in blacks
      and whites using the First National Health and Examination Survey Epidemiologic Follow-up
      Study (NHEFS-I, 11-year follow-up), including this group's own work, demonstrate its
      potential strengths, while at the same time foundering on the problem of low statistical
      power. With the extension of the follow-up of NHANES-I cohort (1971-1974) to 1987 (14 years)
      and the completion of 14-year follow-up for NHANES II cohort (1976-1980), a strong rationale
      exists to undertake a "pooling project." The resulting data set would provide optimal
      characterization of CHD risk at the national level.

      DESIGN NARRATIVE:

      The study sought to determine whether data from NHANES I and NHANES II could be pooled.  To
      accomplish this, the distribution of baseline  measures was assessed and a determination was
      made whether the same logistic prediction equations fitted both studies.  Also, gender-race
      differences were examined in individual exposure-outcome relationships, patterns of
      co-morbidity, and population attributable risks. .

reference.citation: Liao Y, McGee DL, Cooper RS, Sutkowski MB. How generalizable are coronary risk prediction models? Comparison of Framingham and two national cohorts. Am Heart J. 1999 May;137(5):837-45.

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014

clinical_study.source: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (NHLBI)

lead_sponsor.agency: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (NHLBI)
